subject: Terminal -ess, American pronunciation conflict?
msgSnippet: I would like to thank everyone who responded to my original inquiry about terminal -ier for American pronunciation. I have another observation that I would
messageBody:
I would like to thank everyone who responded to my original inquiry
about terminal -ier for American pronunciation. I have another
observation that I would like input on.

On page 20 of the Quikscript manual, it is recommended that for
terminal -ess (and like endings), that letter combination #28+#11 be
used. According to the manual, it should be used to avoid using
#36+#11 again.

My observations for words endings in -ess & the like is that the vowel
sound in this particular set of terminals (-ess, -est, -less & -ness)
tends to be represented in dictionaries available to me (American) by
the "i" sound (letter #26) or the upside-down "e" (letter #36).
Unfortunately, I do not have access to a British dictionary so I am
unaware if, again, this rule favors British pronunciation.

Does anyone know a better rationale for using letter #28 for this set
of terminals? Is it simply to avoid using letter combination #36+#11
over again or does #28+#11 represent the proper British pronunciation.?

I am leaning towards a proposal of using #26+#11 instead for American
pronunciation. This is probably not the optimal solution as some
dictionaries also use the upside-down "e" (letter #36) for the vowel
sound.

Thank you.
